Sarcasm is poison

Apr 17, 2025

When life gets rough, it’s easy to become sarcastic or cynical, but I long ago I came to realize that’s not healthy at all. In a way it’s like really having to pee while being in a swimming pool with others (bear with me). You could be blasÃ© about it, and every time there’s a bitter laugh about the situation, you pee a tiny bit. It’s a big pool, right? No harm done. And the others do it, too! Easy.

Yet do it often enough, and you’re submerged in piss.

Or you could say “I gotta pee”, and get out and go to the restroom, like an adult.

In my opinion, most of the time, that’s the vastly healthier option. It’s not always easy but then again, what is? Not being cynical or sarcastic, and instead being open and honest about an issue, that takes guts. It’s often uncomfortable but knowing that we’ve been true to ourselves is a load-bearing component of our moral foundations.

Because cynicism and sarcasm are poisons which poison the person dishing them out, too. They’re not vents, they’re just terrible feedback loops.

Just something I thought about for no reason. Have a great Thursday, y’all.

Jan 28, 2025

The day the new US monarchy declares they want the Panama Canal “back”, the French govt should request the immediate return of the Statue of Liberty.

Just an idea.

Societal progress isn't a fantasy

Jan 24, 2025

While everything seems to be terribly bleak right now, please remember that not everything is. There’s a lot of good stuff done by good people all around the world.

Societal progress isn’t a fantasy, it’s happening all around us. These #newsletter show what’s already working: climate solutions ready to scale up, environmental policies making progress, successful conservation efforts, and real advances in human rights.

Good things are happening everywhere. Here are a few links to sites and newsletters highlighting those.

  1. FIX THE NEWS is an independent, subscriber-supported publication. Each week, they find 30-40 stories of progress from around the world, and summarise them in a newsletter. In their podcast, they interview people doing extraordinary things to make the world a better place.

  2. POSITIVE NEWS reports socially relevant and uplifting stories of progress, from the global boom in renewable energy to cities that are solving homelessness, highlighting how people, communities and organisations are changing the world for the better.

  3. SQUIRREL NEWS is dedicated to changing perspectives through solutions-oriented journalism, focussing on news that shows original solutions, approaches and ideas. They aim to counterbalance the negativity of mainstream media and profit-driven journalism, with newsletters in German and English.

  4. IMPORTANT NOT IMPORTANT reports on “science for people who give a shit”. They’re “extraordinarily biased” towards reality which I like. Their newsletter also features “what can I do” sections to help you help yourself against the feeling of doom and gloom. They also swear a lot, which â€¦understandable.

  5. And, finally, GOODnews is a curated platform for positive journalism. Every day their team carefully selects fresh, innovative, and inspiring news with positive social, economic, or environmental impact from hundreds of solutions-focused, fact-checked sources. Newsletters in English and German.

There are more, of course. These are just the ones I know.

Media Diet, November 2024

Jan 6, 2025

November was a blur.1 We were preparing for a move (new apartment!) and dealing with a number of things. I didn’t have many spare cycles left for mindful consumption of anything media.

ğŸ® Dragon Age: The Veilguard, Xbox â€“ GLORIOUS. Dragon Age: Inquisition is one of my favourite games of all time, and Veilguard looks like a worthy follow-up, at the very least!

Elle Griffin: Mondragon as the new City-State â€“ Great, clear-eyed independent look at one of the largest group of worker coÃ¶perations in the World, the Mondragon Corporation in Spains Basque region. Which exists for almost 70Â years at this point and is very successful in creating wealth, global business, with happy workers, and great living conditions for the region.

Greg Pogorzelski: “The thing about the Kobayashi Maru” â€“ TOS fan fiction. Kirk and Bones discussing the famous Starfleet no-win scenario sim.

ğŸ¤ Janine Harouni: “Stand Up With Janine Harouni (Please Remain Seated)" â€“ Nice, personal hour of stand up. It starts a bit slow; she talks about moving to Europe, and how she deals with family voting for Trump in 2016, but takes up steam after a few minutes. She weaves a nice narrative, and it feels like it’s coming from the heart, jokes and views and everything. I liked it.

ğŸ¤ Joel McHale: “Live from Pyongyang” â€“ Fun. It’s basically McHale talking about different gigs he did and cities he went to. It might sounds a bit like “all over the place”, good, because that’s what the special is, but I enjoyed the pace and his occasional “squirrel on meth” delivery.

Default Apps 2024

Dec 8, 2024

Another year has gone by, and my toolkit hasn’t changed much since the last time I did a post like thisâ€¦

ğŸ“¨ Mail Client:Â Fastmate

ğŸ“® Mail Server:Â Fastmail (since 2013!)

ğŸ“† Calendar:Â Fastmail via Fantastical

ğŸ“ Cloud File Storage:Â Fastmail, iCloud Drive, and Hetzner Storage Box

ğŸ™ğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸ Contacts:Â Fastmail via Cardhop

ğŸ“ Notes:Â Obsidian

âœ… To-Do:Â Obsidian for day-to-day business-related work and high-level planning, Linear for (code) project planning and issues, Apple Reminders for personal stuff

ğŸ’¶ Banking: MoneyMoney

ğŸ”– Bookmarks:Â Obsidian, but to be fair, I don’t bookmark much these days.

ğŸ“– RSS:Â Feedbin (for the 3rd year in a row!)

ğŸ“‘ Read It Later:Â Feedbin

ğŸŒ Browser: Vivaldi, but currently test-driving Orion for macOS and really liking what I see!

ğŸ’¬ Chat:Â Telegram, Signal, WhatsApp, and all of them mostly through the macOS Beeper client).Â Slack but only rarely.

ğŸ›’ Shopping Lists:Â Apple Reminders

ğŸ¤ Podcasts:Â Pocketcasts

ğŸ” Password Management:Â Strongbox

ğŸ“¼ Backup: Arq, Hetzner Storage Box for storage

ğŸš€ Launcher: I’m firmly back in the Alfred camp.

ğŸ“ˆ Metrics: iStat Menus

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Code Editor:Â VS Code, Xcode + Copilot Plus for Xcode (see “LLM”, below), Script Debugger 8

ğŸ’» Terminal: iTerm

ğŸ‘¨ğŸ¼â€ğŸ« Making Videos & Tutorials: DaVinci Resolve, currently switching over to ScreenFlow.

ğŸ™ï¸ Dictation & Transcriptions: MacWhisper

ğŸ¹ Music: Apple Music (because TIDAL’s apps are terrible at almost everything), Doppler (iOS)

ğŸŒ… Photo Management: Apple Photos

ğŸ› ï¸ Automation: Keyboard Maestro, Apple Shortcuts

ğŸ¤– LLMs + “AI”: For most things, including work on my Swift code, I prefer Anthropic’s Claude 3.5 Sonnet over any other model. On the Mac I use BoltAI for “LLM chatting”. In general, I tend to connect to any remote LLM by way of OpenRouter (a unified interface for accessing various large language models), because it allows me to mix and match as I go without having to pay monthly subs for different LLM providers. It’s great.

ğŸ¤ Gary Gulman: “Born on 3rd Base” (2023) â€“ For me personally, a funnier special than his previous two.

ğŸ® PowerWash Simulator | Xbox â€“ I have no excuse. I liked it a lot for some reason. At some point my mind turned this game into part 2 of the excellent Everybody’s Gone to the Rapture. You’re alone and hallucinating conversations with ghosts and other people that you never see, while cleaning what they have left behind.

ğŸ“š Trevor Hopkins: “Dark Matter” â€“ A fan fiction Culture novel, and I gotta say, this worked very well for me. If you miss Iain M. Banks as much as I do, and long for new Culture stories, check out Mr. Hopkins' catalogue!

We only learnt of our sonâ€™s secret online life after he died at 20 â€“ “When Mats Steen died from a muscle-wasting disorder, his parents believed that his life had been a tragically lonely one â€” until hundreds of emails from strangers arrived. It turns out that heâ€™d found friendship and even romance in a gaming community”. I’ve cried a little bit reading that article.

ğŸ® Hellblade: Senua’s Sacrifice | Xbox â€“ Looks and sounds fabulous, but I’ve dropped the game after a few hours; I just can’t deal with its whole everything right now.

ğŸ¤ Kurt Braunohler: “Perfectly Stupid” (2022) â€“ Good stand-up special from a comic I hadn’t heard of before.

ğŸ® Sifu, Xbox â€“ A lovely Kung Fu game. I love the idea, I love the look, I lack the skill.

ğŸ® Donut County, Xbox â€“ Short, sweet, cute game where you play a hole in the ground, mostly. I liked it!

ğŸ¤ Tom Papa: Human Mule (2016) â€” Two weeks later, I don’t remember anything from that hour, though. But I know I enjoyed it while it lasted.

ğŸ¤ Steve Hofstetter: “Secret Optimist” â€“ Hilarious stand-up special. Time well spent.

ğŸ¤ Steve Hofstetter: “The Recipe” â€“ Excellent, very personal stand-up comedy special. This one had me lightly tear up once or twice. I love comics that tell personal stories, not just jokes.

ğŸ“š Phoebe_Zeitgeist: “Standard Operating Equipment”, Archive of Our Own â€“ A short fan fiction story, placed in the late, great Iain M. Banks' Culture universe. The bar is high; Banks made sure of that with his original works. This one did really well, I think.

Noland Arbaugh, First Human w/ Neuralink Implant Tells His Story â€“ A supercut version of Noland Arbaugh’s Neuralink session where he talks about his experience of being the first person to receive an actual Neuralink brain-computer interface device, which lets him control his iPad and play games, all with his mind. Nolan’s quadriplegic since an accident several years ago. For a moment, ignore who set up that company, how much of a thundercunt their CEO is, etc. Concentrate on listening to Arbaugh talk about his work on & with Neuralink â€“ it’s crazy inspiring and mindboggling. Just awesome technological progress, really.

ğŸ“š Iain M. Banks: “Inversions” â€“ I’ve read this novel many years ago, and didn’t remember much about it. I’m happy to report it’s still very good.

The Race to Harness Quantum Computing’s Mind-Bending Power | The Future With Hannah Fry, YouTube â€“ Super interesting look at what’s going on in quantum computing, for normal’ish people. Things are gonna get real wild soon, I think. So far I liked the entire “The Future With Hannah Fry” series on YT.

John Oliver Is Still Working Through the Rage, YouTube â€“ Aren’t we all? Good man.

Fears and Thoughts After the 2024 US Elections

Nov 7, 2024

Some things I believe might happen in the next few years, in response to the utterly insane 2024 US election that went to Trump. I just want to get this shit out of my head onto another canvas so it doesn’t circle around in my brain the entire time. I need to function, and that ever-present feeling of doom and dread doesn’t help.

Preface: These are just the high-level thoughts my brain spit out. Don’t get me started on the emotional, person-level fears I have for the human beings who’ll have cruelty inflicted on them.

With that said:

  1. Trump has no interest in doing any work, and he’s on his last leg, so this will turn into a quasi-Vance presidency quickly.
  2. We’ll get reliable proof that there was some heavy Russian election interference going on, including hacking of voting systems. The ruling US fascists won’t follow-up on this because they got what they wanted.
  3. If everyone is bending the knee before the new king, there won’t be any more “checks and balances”.
  4. The US will mostly withdraw from NATO, or at least meet its obligations with indifference.
    1. Russia will intensify its war efforts in Ukraine because Trump has already stated he doesn’t care, so â€¦ free reign, less backup for Ukraine.
    2. This will embolden China to invade Taiwan because it knows Trump doesn’t care understand. Taiwan no longer being a free country will also have the side-effect of the World’s biggest chip foundry being Chinese all of a sudden.
    3. Russia will start fucking with the other countries which declared their independence from the fallen Soviet Union.
  5. The other NATO members will (hopefully) stick together, because they understand what’s on the line, namely Europe. Several countries will re-introduce mandatory service (looking at my home country Germany here).
  6. The GOP will continue their good work on building a well-functioning1 mafia state where everything is beholden to the don, using the successful Putin blueprint. This will take decades to undo, if ever.
  7. Britain at least seriously considers re-joining the EU.
  8. Climate protection is no longer on the table for the US. They left the Paris climate accord right after Trump’s 1st term started, and they’ll do the same again. The US gov’t will curtail the powers of the EPA (again), with renewed vigor, or shut it down entirely.
    • Remember in 2017, when the US government agencies weren’t allowed to even mention climate change on their websites?
    • Thankfully, renewables have proven themselves in terms of generating money, so that might make it harder to shut down in favor of fossil fuels etc.
  9. It’s a given that the climate crisis will worsen, the US will be hit hard, there’ll be some major disasters. (Same thing all around the World.) The US gov’t fascists have already killed off a ton of crisis response departments at that point (“small government!!"), so the responses won’t be enough, and there’ll be rioting. Remember hurricane Katrina? That, but not just once, and much worse.

At the moment of this writing, half the US population is comfortable with Project 2025, a Russian-style mafia state oligarchy, and the “every man for himself” mentality (which is notably not gender-neutral). So where does that leave the other half? I cannot imagine them being accepting of this direct assault on their human rights and core values. Because from what I can tell, they fundamentally reject the “survival of the fittest” and “know your place” principles that underpin the GOP’s authoritarian agenda. Currently, there are laws that address injustices, and courts to handle such matters, but what if that changes due to partisan reconstruction of the legal system?

I certainly think that there’s a lot of civic unrest on the table for the US. It wouldn’t surprise me if the king would get his wish of the military keeping the order â€“ on which side, who knows.

But for the rest of the world, too, this election changes a lot of constants. I certainly hope my home (the EU) gets its shit together, and finally creates a strong, unified, economic and military defense force soon.

Big sigh.

On a very personal level, here’s is what makes my skin crawl the most:

My grandma lived through World War II, her family was decimated by the German Nazis. My parents and I were born and grew up in the former East Germany, a satellite state of “big brother Russia.” The latter was not terrible by any stretch, but it was not freedom. I do not want to see the day when autocratic Russia seeks to return to its imagined former glory by invading its old territories.

  1. “Well-functioning” for you if you’re white, 8-figures-plus kind of rich, straight, male. ↩︎

I was surprised myself, but I spent several hours watching outsidexbox’s videos and live streams on Youtube. Just what the doctor ordered: A great team of adults with good chemistry, playing games I don’t want to play but enjoy watching, bantering. Entertaining.

ğŸ¥ Tenet (2020) â€” Late to the party as usual, but I’ve enjoyed that weird-ass movie quite a bit. Bit of a brain twister story, well executed!

ğŸ¶ Rakim: “G.O.Ds NETWORK - REB7RTH” â€“ If you’re in the market for good, new, old school hip hop by one of the greats, I can recommend this EP. It just clicks with me, hard.

ğŸ“º Infiniti (2022) â€” This 6-part, French scifi mystery series came out of nowhere for me. Part murder mystery, part Baikonur space drama, I really liked it. If you’re kinda bored by the same-same of US/UK SF shows, it might be worth your while. Different pace, different setting, different way to tell a story.

ğŸ¥ Bad Moms (2016) â€“ Surprisingly funny. Didn’t expect anything, and it delivered a good number of laughs.

ğŸ¤ Steve Hofstetter: “Me, Myself, and ID” â€“ A really good, super-solid, somewhat political comedy special. Hofstetter’s delivery is on point on several levels. And for me it had a number of laugh-out-loud moments! (A)

ğŸ¤ Taylor Tomlinson: “Have It All” (2024) â€“ Tomlinson is good, I like her comedy a lot. To me, her style of comedy feels like “working things out on stage”, and I’m here for that. (See also her earlier special “Quarter-Life Crisis”.)

ğŸ¤ My Next Guest with David Letterman and John Mulaney (2024) â€“ Two of the greats. Mulaney appears to be so much more â€¦grounded these days, which actually makes me happy for him.

ğŸ¥ The Gray Man (2022) â€“ Perfectly fine action flick with Ryan Gosling and Chris Evans' mustache. Nothing to write home about but well done. I won’t forget it anytime soon, however, only because I watched it on a hotel room Samsung smart TV, and that screen’s picture “optimizations” made the whole movie look like a cheap-ass telenovela, which angered me far more that is reasonable.

TIL How to Use the Mac's `fn` Key with Keyboard Maestro

Aug 10, 2024

TIL that when you use the venerable keyboard customizer Karabiner Elements on macOS, Karabiner will emit a USB device key signal for the fn/ğŸŒ key. This is great because I can now tell Keyboard Maestro (and likely BetterTouchTool, too) to use a fn press as a macro trigger!

For example, this is how it looks when I configured âŒ˜fn as such a trigger:

Useful!

A roundup of noteworthy things Iâ€™ve played, read, listened to, or watched over the last few weeks. Busy times, so I kind of forgot about this list, so I’m trying to reconstruct it from memory. Which, incidentally, is a good yard stick! If I can remember it, it obviously was “noteworthy”, right? That’s just science, people.

ğŸ¥ The Fall Guy (2024) â€“ Loved it. The whole movie just worked for me. Jolly good fun!

ğŸ“º Star Wars: The Acolyte â€“ Slow start. Didn’t look like the usual Disney SW (“shovel ware”) in the beginning, which was nice. Over the course of the season, it became â€¦muddled, to the point of feeling, well, pointless. My current pet theory (one that I hate having, mind) is that in season 2 the new power couple is gonna make a force baby which will one day become Emperor Palpatine. Disney’s Star Wars, where anything not related to Episode I-VI goes to die. I think I’m finally over filmic entertainment involving lightsabers.

Who Is Neuralink’s First Patient? Noland Arbaugh on His Brain Implant - Bloomberg (Archived) â€“ Noland Arbaugh became the first human to receive Neuralink’s brain-computer interface implant. The device allows him to control a computer with his thoughts, overcoming his physical limitations after a tragic accident left him paralyzed. Ignore everything “Elon Musk” in this article, and focus on the technological marvel on display. Super cool stuff.

ğŸ® STAR WARS Jedi: Survivorâ„¢, Xbox GamePass Ultimate â€“ Cal Kestis is back, baby! Bit of a slow start for me, but then it clicked just like Fallen Order did. Turns out I’m a Single+Blaster stance type of guy, I didn’t expect that. The seriousâŸºsilly spread is pretty wide, though. On one hand, you have epic Jedi/ fate/ betrayal stuff, on the other, Space Cowboy Kermit ğŸ¸

ğŸ“º Tales from the Loop: Season 1 (2020) â€“ Slow, ponderous, weird-ass stories from a time and place that never were. They captured the 80s/90s look exceedingly well, and paired it with some believable machine design, there’s much to love about it. Watched the first few episodes. As I’ve said, they’re slow but good; not very dense, but they were given a sensible amount of space to develop and breathe. Like it.

ğŸ“š Arthur C. Clarke: “Rendezvous with Rama” â€“ After hearing again and again how much of an influential masterpiece it is, I finally decided to pick it up for the first time. Got three chapters in on the last days of July. We’ll see!

ğŸ® Despicable Me 4 (2024) â€“ Did laugh a lot. I like that series, unadulterated silly fun, and there’s just something about Steve Carell doing Gru that cracks me up every time.

ğŸ¶ Chase & Status: “More Than Alot” â€“ Catching up on my 2008+ drum’n’bass. Good music to work to, with “Against All Odds (feat. Kano)” being a solid standout.

ğŸ¤ Nate Bargatze: Hello World (2023) â€“ Super-enjoyable comedy special by one of the current greats. I’m a fan of NB since I first came across The Tennessee Kid (2019) years ago, and subsequently worked my way through his back catalog. Hilarious on so many levels.

Media Diet, May 2024

Jun 8, 2024

A roundup of noteworthy things Iâ€™ve played, read, listened to, or watched over the last few weeks. In May, we were on vacation in Sweden in celebration of our respective birthdays, and I still am/was working a lot on my new macOS app, UI Actions. (Which is coming along quite nicely, thank you!)

Redwood Material’s Nevada EV Battery Recycling Facility Attempts to Rival China - Bloomberg (Archive) â€“ Recycling FTW. But this venture there, man! Staggering numbers, really hard for me to visualize. Very, very cool. “While the toll of mining the raw materials for batteries is considerable, more than 95% of the key minerals can be profitably recycled. At Redwood, nothing goes to landfill, and no water leaves the facility except the sanitary waste from sinks and toilets. There are no gas lines; everything is electric. Itâ€™s also built for scale, allowing the company to quickly break down a truckload of assorted batteries without manual sorting or tedious disassembly."

ğŸ¤ Fern Brady: “Power & Chaos”, YouTube â€“ Standup special by Scottish comedienne Fern Brady. Loved it. I’m man enough to admit I had to use CC every now and then. ğŸ˜…

ğŸ¤ Fern Brady: “Male Comedienne” â€“ After seeing “Power & Chaos” I had to check out her other stuff, too. I’m ESL, and while she’s sometimes hard to understand (because Scottish is beautiful but also very much its own thing) she’s never not funny.

ğŸ“º Star Wars: Tales of the Jedi â€“ Nice yet forgettable, like most SW stuff these days. I’d take one more episode of Andor over this any day.

ğŸ“š “Altered Carbon” by Richard K. Morgan â€“ Re-read. Still a very, very tight and satisfying cyberpunk novel.

ğŸ¤ Aaron Woodall: “No One Pretends To Be Religious” â€“ Stand-up special by a former Mormon. I mention this because he himself is riding that “ex-Mormon” train hard here but it didn’t do much for me.

ğŸ¶ “Radical Optimism” by Dua Lipa â€“ An unsurprisingly1 upbeat album, musically. Nice.

ğŸ® Star Wars Jedi: Survivor â€“ Started getting into this one at the end of the month. I’m not too far in, just left the first tutorial planet. I hope it’ll be as satisfying an experience as its predecessor, Fallen Order.

Media Diet, April 2024

May 5, 2024

A roundup of noteworthy things Iâ€™ve played, read, listened to, or watched over the last few weeks. Not much, this time; I am/was working a lot, new macOS app and all.

Late Night with Seth Meyers on YouTube â€“ Love it. When he talks about “jackals”, I feel wholly included, which either tells you everything you need to know about my sense of humor, or nothing at all.

ğŸ¤ “Live (At the Time)” by Demetri Martin â€“ I had a blast listening to this stand-up special, but it’s a different form than what I’m used to. It’s basically just a more or less random list of hilarious observations and one-liners; this description makes it sound more disjointed than it actually is. Good stuff.

ğŸ® Destiny 2 â€“ After 2+ years of absence, I picked up the so-called “Legacy Collections”, containing yester-years' three big DLCs (Shadowkeep, Beyond Light, The Witch Queen), and am solo’ing my way through them. It’s still Destiny, for sure, even though they’ve changed a lot over the years. I’m having fun, 15â‚¬ well spent. I’m currently in the first chapters of the Witch Queen DLC, and it’s pretty nice! Haven’t decided yet whether to buy Lightfall after that, or The Final Shape.

We should all be reading more Ursula Le Guin | The Outline â€“ I love the idea, the whole mindset. “The Carrier Bag Theory of Fiction [â€¦] disputes the idea that the spear was the earliest human tool, proposing that it was actually the receptacle. Questioning the spearâ€™s phallic, murderous logic, instead Le Guin tells the story of the carrier bag, the sling, the shell, or the gourd. In this empty vessel, early humans could carry more than can be held in the hand and, therefore, gather food for later. Anyone who consistently forgets to bring their tote bag to the supermarket knows how significant this is. And besides, Le Guin writes, the idea that the spear came before the vessel doesnâ€™t even make sense." I need to check my local library for some of ULG’s books.

ğŸ“š “Leave the World Behind” by Rumaan Alam â€“ What a courageous book. As in: I think it takes a certain kind of courage to call it a day when your book is only 2/3 done. It wasn’t a terrible read, but I felt like it was making promises all the time it couldn’t keep. Both book blurbs and the related movie trailer made it sound quite VanderMeerâ€™ian â€“ I was expecting some New Weird, but it isn’t that. In fact, I’m not sure what that book even wants to be. There’s a lot of spooky foreshadowing both by the narrator (“the trees knew”, “old folks know”, “kids can hear ghosts” etc.) and dramatic plot points (people getting sick etc.), and nothing. comes. of. it. And then it ends. It just ends. (C)

ğŸ¤ “People Make Mistakes” by J.F. Harris, YouTube â€“ Hilarious stand-up special.

ğŸ¤˜ğŸ¼ Live In Texas (Full) - Linkin Park â€” Linkin Park’s 2003 live performance. Always worth a rewatch.

ğŸ“º 7 Days in Hell (2015) â€“ Tennis is deeply weird. Also, ~30 mins is the right length for a piece like this. Hilarious if you’re a bit weird and/or like Samberg mockumentaries (like “Popstar”), probably unwatchable otherwise.

STORROR on YouTube â€“ Every Monday, like clockwork. I like watching their training and challenges etc., they’re an enjoyable bunch. If you haven’t watched their film “Roof Culture Asia” yet, I recommend it if you’re interested in parkour.

Media Diet, March 2024

Apr 14, 2024

A roundup of noteworthy things Iâ€™ve played, read, listened to, or watched over the last few weeks. A bit late, as usual, so â€¦ not really late.

ğŸ“š “Childhood’s End” by Arthur C. Clarke â€“ A classic scifi work, new to me. Enjoyable, and painted in broad-enough strokes to not feel super-old. I love reading these really old foundational works and then discovering their clear influences in other novels, movies, stories that came later.

ğŸ§© “My little World” Round Puzzle by Londji & Cinta Vidal â€“ Not strictly media, but D and I did spend an inordinate amount of time on this beautiful, circular, 500-piece jigsaw puzzle. Very meditative. Loved it. (A+)

ğŸ¤ “Shocks & Struts” by Kyle Kinane â€“ Fun stand-up set by Kinane. Did LOL a few times. (A)

ğŸ“º Star Trek: Strange New Worlds: Season 2 (2023) â€“ Something about SNW just feels right. Is it the simple one-story-per-episode structure? Is it Anson Mount’s fabulous hair, or Melissa Navia’s equally rad cut? The chemistry between the people on set? I don’t know, but it just works. We’re still in the middle of S02, and enjoying it a lot. (A)

ğŸ® Chorus â€“ A space shootybang. Tight control, great presentation, but it just didn’t click with me. Apparently I’m not the kid anymore who played the shit out of Descent et al.

ğŸ® Everspace 2 â€“ Another space looter-shooter. See Chorus, above.

ğŸ¤ “Greatest Bits, Vol. 1” by Kathleen Madigan â€“ Super-solid standup set by a comedian I had never heard of before. I had fun! (B+)

ğŸ® Horizon Zero Dawnâ„¢ Complete Edition â€“ I’ve almost 100%’d HZD on my PS4 Pro a few years back. I loved everything about it so very much. Since I don’t have a PS4 anymore, I decided to pick it up on GOG for PC, and give it a shot on my MacBook (M1 Pro) using Heroic Games Launcher and Whisky. I was surprised how relatively painless the installation is and how well it runs, even with everything set to High or Ultra. (A+)

  • “Nahiku West” by Linda Nagata
  • “Martian Blood” by Allen M. Steele
  • “Stones” by Nnedi Okorafor

Media Diet, February 2024

Mar 9, 2024

A roundup of noteworthy things Iâ€™ve played, read, listened to, or watched over the last few weeks.

It was a busy month, and I didn’t have much time for reading a book or playing some games. It happens. March is going better already. ğŸ˜‰

ğŸ™ï¸ “Socio” by Daniel Sloss â€“ Funny stand up special by a funny Scotsman, a bit crass at times, enjoyable. I liked his earlier specials a bit more; I think it has something to do with him not being as professionally self-assured as he is now, if that makes any sense.

“Maps Distort How We See the World” by Tomas Pueyo â€“ Absolutely mind blowing. The most-used map projection entirely distorts the size of continents, countries, the poles. Just take a look at the first correction (a GIF) in the article!

ğŸ“š “Acceptance” by Jeff VanderMeer â€“ The eerie conclusion to VanderMeer’s “Southern Reach” trilogy. Good read, adding quite a bit of depth to many characters. I loved how he threw some curve balls with minor details, like the thing with the old cell phone. Good ending, all in all. (A)

ğŸ“º Halo, Season 2, by people who don’t give a shit about established lore, I think â€“ I’m not fond of this “Silver timeline” at all (it’s called that because, holy shit, it sure ain’t gold). I do like Pablo Schreiber’s gruff MC, and he’s out of armor 90% of the time for some reason. Outstanding: Natasha Culzac’s depiction of Riz-028 growing from Spartan into an actual person, that was really good. I hate how they wasted some lore-important Key(es) characters for cheap drama. I don’t like the weird-ass “human part of the Covenant” bollocks. I’d love to know what Makee’s hair dresser thinks they are doing over there. This show is a bit of a train wreck, but I can’t seem to look away. If you have no idea what Halo is or how the original story went, it’s probably more enjoyable. (C-)

ğŸ“º Three-Body: ä¸‰ä½“ â€“ There is this supposedly very faithful 30-part Chinese TV adaptation of “The Three-Body Problem” by Cixin Liu. Each episode is over 40 minutes long. They sure take their sweet time with the show, and after four episodes I threw in the towel. It’s very well done, I think, but this show is not made for me.

Death, Lonely Death â€” Crooked Timber â€“ A beautiful ode to the engineering marvel that is Voyager I. Godspeed, little one. You did great.

ğŸ™ï¸ “No Questions Asked” by Matt Goldich â€“ He is one of the writers of “Late Night with Seth Meyers”, which is how I discovered this special. It’s not ROFL material to me, but I had a good time! I laughed, and that’s always nice. (B)

ğŸ™ï¸ “The Matt Goldich Guarantee” by Matt Goldich â€“ His first album/ special. Good jokes, dry delivery, really liked it! (B+)

“The Tyranny of Convenience” by Tim Wu (Archived) â€“ Well-written plea to choose your battles wisely:

What happens to human experience when so many obstacles and impediments and requirements and preparations have been removed? Todayâ€™s cult of convenience fails to acknowledge that difficulty is a constitutive feature of human experience. Convenience is all destination and no journey. But climbing a mountain is different from taking the tram to the top, even if you end up at the same place.

“Niuniu” by Baoshu, translated by Andy Dudak : Clarkesworld Magazine â€“ Science Fiction & Fantasy â€“ Novelette by Chinese scifi author Baoshu. What would you do if live took a person you loved, and you could “bring them back” in a way? A bit depressing.

Lone Echo | Full Game Walkthrough | YouTube â€“ A VR game walkthrough. I had heard good things about Lone Echo, but don’t own anything that could play it, so I went to YT on a whim. Nice story, well presented.

“Don Putin and his enemies” by Krautreporter â€“ Here’s a great “Russian govt” explainer article from one of my fave German journalist crews, Krautreporter. It was published in German, but Google Translate did a good job, so I wholeheartedly recommend reading and spreading it:

Russia has become a mafia state, with a powerful boss at the top: Vladimir Putin. Many of his decisions seem irrational, and many events in Russia seem completely insane, such as Prigozhin’s attempted coup. But if you understand Russia as a mafia state, then the coup attempt is a war between two rival gangs. And a lot of other things suddenly make sense.

A roundup of noteworthy things Iâ€™ve played, read, listened to, or watched over the last few weeks.

ğŸ“º For All Mankind: Season 3 â€“ They don’t let up! The farther the show goes into speculative territory, the broader it gets. And it felt a bit rushed at times. High points: everything on Mars, even if the timing and logistics of the North Korean capsule don’t make sense to me (did they travel from Earth to Mars in that bucket? Seems unlikely). Low points: anything with the Stevens brothers, my goodness. (A)

ğŸ“º For All Mankind: Season 4 â€“ The world building of this last season is still great, but in terms of stories, I didn’t like the distinct feeling of “too many arcs, not enough time”, as a few threads were left hanging or were buried abruptly (Kelly, anyone?). I’ve enjoyed the whole of it, but it was tonally different from the previous seasons. Side note: Ed Baldwin had a somewhat odd character arc, didn’t he? At this point, I fully expect him to open a detective agency on Phobos in S05. (B+)

ğŸ“š “Elder Race” by Adrian Tchaikovsky â€“ A novella that takes up Clarke’s third law nicely. I found the insight into the anthropologist’s emotional life and the description of his depression very well realized. (B)

ğŸ¶ Mike Shinoda: Post Traumatic (2018) â€“ I think it was his first solo album after Chester Bennington’s death, and you can feel a lot of pain. Not an easy listen, even though it is as tight as ever.

ğŸ“š “Annihilation” by Jeff VanderMeer â€“ Weird, very weird. It tells a different story than the movie adaptation, I think. Still, the good kind of weird. (B+)

ğŸ“š “Authority” by Jeff VanderMeer â€“ The follow-up to Annihilation. It is said that VanderMeer’s “Southern Reach” trilogy was a big influence for Remedy, the makers of the excellent game “Control” (which I replayed in December), and yeah, I see a lot of parallels. It has a somewhat unsettling feel to it, which I liked a lot. (A)

66 Good News Stories You Didn’t Hear About in 2023 â€“ Focussing on what went well, on causes for celebration and hope. It’s a good list! (A+)

Germanyâ€™s surging far right Alternative for Germany party provokes a reckoning - The Washington Post â€“ I won’t lie, it felt good to get out there and finally see that turnout. We are many! Also, the official numbers reported by the police are notoriously too low. In Munich, roughly 200k people showed up, not 100k. Anyways, the far-right’s narrative of “silent majority” is obviously utter bullshit. Don’t ever believe their brown hype, people. (Archived)

ğŸ¶ TIDAL - High Fidelity Music Streaming â€“ Somewhat turned off by the business side of Spotify, I decided to give their competitor TIDAL a try, not least because the payout for the streamed artists is apparently quite a bit higher than with other services. It’s good, I guess? I kind of miss Spotify’s “Discover Weekly” list, which did a much better job of surfacing music that’s new to me. And even if their catalogs are comparable, I feel that in the curation department, Spotify has the upper hand. And navigating from a currently playing song from a playlist to the album feels a bit off to me. In any case, both services ask for â‚¬11/month. But artist payout is important to me, so TIDAL it is.

Sep 25, 2023

Japan pharma startup developing world-first drug to grow new teeth

Most people have “tooth buds” that have the potential to become a new tooth, in addition to baby and permanent teeth, although the buds usually do not develop and subsequently disappear.

The team created an antibody drug that inhibits the protein that suppresses the growth of teeth. The drug works on these buds and stimulates their growth.

Sep 23, 2023

Slowly regaining some energy. I think I got a bit of a cold a few days ago, which went nicely with my existing general exhaustion. Took a few days off for the most part, even though that means I’ve to push the TestFlight for #BrowserActions back a few days.

My health is more important than my apps.

Burnout 2021

Sep 16, 2023

This day in 2021 was the first day of my 3-month burnout sabbatical.

I had been increasingly overworked for 2-3 years at this point, we were building a sensible and sustainable company, I was way too stressed all the time, and was struggling so. fukken. hard. Still, I kept pushing through, but I felt like I was a week away from going Hindenburg 1937. Then, that Friday evening, my good friend and co-founder Florian showed up unannounced at our doorstep, and told me, “Buddy, you’re toast. Take a few months off, just get better.â€ My crew had noticed, he had noticed, and they acted.

I’m still very grateful to them.

And the first weeks were brutal. I had such a hard time deciding anything. Answering a simple question like “Want some coffee?â€ was hard. My wife carried my sorry ass for weeks. I had completely drained my batteries which (among other things) were also powering my decision-making processes, which was weird AF.

I remember going for a walk in Munich, and there was a fork in a road â€” both paths would take me to the same destination. Still, I stood there dumbfounded for a few minutes.

Anyways. I was able to take my time, I got better, I found out why I was stressed, and ultimately, I came to the conclusion that I had to leave the company I had helped found and loved dearly. I wasn’t the right person for that particular job anymore, and the company wasn’t the right fit for me anymore. Which was a sad yet elating conclusion, like growing up or something.

2023: We’ve changed many more things, moved way up North, I’m an indie dev now, and my wife says I look much better these days. â¤ï¸

Life is pretty good right now is what I’m saying. Getting stuck can get you killed, and you’re never to old to make some changes.

It’s amazing the dark places you can end up, even when the work is meaningful, the people are great, and there’s a real, global purpose. (I had all three of those things: We were building a Germany-wide deposit system for reusable coffee cups and take-out containers. Basically a waste reduction system on a gigantic scale. Good, important work on an actual problem.)

An interesting lesson, that.

Actions for Obsidian: iOS Launch!

Jun 6, 2023

Actions for Obsidian v1.1 for iOS is finally here!

Many thanks to all the testers who sent in bug reports and feedback over the last months! ğŸ™ğŸ¼

How much does Actions for Obsidian cost?

Short answer: Just like the macOS app, the iOS app is free to download from the App Store. There is a 14+ day trial period. Afterwards you need a license. Single-platform licenses (iOS or macOS) are $9/ $12/ $15, depending on what you think is a fair price!

Detailed answer: How much does Actions for Obsidian cost? - Actions for Obsidian: Knowledge Base

I decided against subscription pricing, even though it would have been a better choice financially. But I personally prefer software that I can buy rather than rent, because it gives me independence from the fate of the company that makes it. (Here, I exclude tools that rely on server components which need regular maintenance etc.)

Available â€¦World-wide?

Almost. The app is available in 174 out of 175 App Stores â€” I know it’s merely a symbolic gesture, but I’ve excluded Russia until they stop their unprovoked war against Ukraine.

Ğ¡Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ° Ğ£ĞºÑ€Ğ°Ñ—Ğ½Ñ–! ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ğŸ––ğŸ¼

What’s next?

I’ll publish my public roadmap soon; there’s a solid backlog of new ideas and feature requests, and I’d like my customers to get a glimpse of what’s planned for the next versions. I’ll keep you posted!

TIL How to use the macOS `security` CLI tool for scripting

Apr 30, 2023

One of my biggest small wins this month: learning how the macOS security CLI tool works. It can store and retrieve Keychain entries:

1ï¸âƒ£ security add-generic-password -a czottmann -s "My secret API key" -w asks for the PW and stores it.

2ï¸âƒ£ security find-generic-password -a czottmann -s "My secret API key" -w retrieves and outputs it.

Super useful: if you store a password like this, security automatically whitelists itself for password-less access to that particular password, meaning it’s trivial to fetch passwords from the Keychain in scripts.

TIL How To Batch-Process Audio Files With Effect Chains

Mar 22, 2023

Every now and then I record an audio file for a tutorial or some such. I always do it in the same place, with the same equipment. And then I have to clean it up using VST/AU plug-ins in a DAW (digital audio workstation).

Today I learned how to automate this process using REAPER, a very nice, very scriptable, very powerful DAW. Because TIL that Reaper comes with a CLI!

Basically, the Reaper CLI allows me to call it with a file containing processing instructions. The file must contain both paths to audio files and details about what to do with them. My example file ~/Desktop/process.txt looks like this:

/Users/czottmann/Desktop/audio-track-1.wav
/Users/czottmann/Desktop/audio-track-2.wav
<CONFIG
  FXCHAIN "Tutorials.RfxChain"
  OUTPATH "/Users/czottmann/Desktop/processed-tracks/"
>

The file paths are pretty self-explanatory, the interesting part is the <CONFIG â€¦> directive. As described in the docs, I tell Reaper to use an FX chain called “Tutorial” and save the processed files in ~/Desktop/processed-tracks/.

The “Tutorials” FX chain didn’t exist, I needed to create it first. So, in Reaper:

  1. I imported an applicable audio file into Reaper. (For setting my baseline, the applicable audio file was one of the voiceovers I did for a tutorial.)
  2. I configured the FX chain for that track. Gate, de-esser, compressor etc.
  3. I saved the FX chain using the name â€œTutorialsâ€ in Reaper’s default FX chains directory.

And with that done, the CLI could be used:

/Applications/REAPER.app/Contents/MacOS/REAPER \
  -batchconvert ~/Desktop/process.txt

Reaper starts up, does the processing, saves the results in the output folder (which should be created beforehand), and quit once done.

Pretty cool.

#til

Actions for Obsidian: macOS Launch!

Mar 13, 2023

In the last month, a few TestFlight pre-release builds happened. I’ve documented all 38 Shortcuts actions in the new Actions Library (part of the brand-new Knowledge Base!). I’ve implemented the payment and licensing! Then there were a few rounds of the fabled App Store review process! Very exciting.

Oh, and also â€¦

Â 

It’s Launch Day on macOS! ğŸš€

Actions for Obsidian v1.0 is finally here! Get it from the Mac App Store or read on to learn more. Or check it out right now, then come back and read the rest. Or read this newsletter, then visit the App Store. (My point is: please do check it out, thanks.)

Â 

Â 

How much does Actions for Obsidian cost?

The app is free to download from the Mac App Store. There is a 14+ day trial period. After the initial trial period, the Shortcuts actions will trigger “Please buy” reminder dialogs.

A license removes these reminders.

You can choose one of three price levels depending on how much you think is fair:

  • “S” (â‚¬11 / $9)
  • “M” (â‚¬14 / $12)
  • “L” (â‚¬17 / $15)

These licenses differ only in price.

It’s an experiment in fairness, basically. For example, I hope that if you use Actions for Obsidian in a commercial setting, you consider buying the “L” license. Or even if it’s for personal use, and you feel it makes you 5Ã— as productive, you might select something else than the “S” level. It is entirely up to you, though.

Â 

Available â€¦World-wide?

Almost. The app is available in 174 out of 175 App Stores â€” I know it’s merely a symbolic gesture, but I’ve excluded Russia until they stop their unprovoked war against Ukraine.

Ğ¡Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ° Ğ£ĞºÑ€Ğ°Ñ—Ğ½Ñ–! ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ğŸ––ğŸ¼

Â 

What’s next?

I am currently researching actions for working with front matter and for dealing with Obsidian Sync. And it’s probably a safe bet that a bug or two will pop up â€” if you find something weird or need help, just open the app and click the “Send Feedback” button or the entry in the Help menu.

But first, I want to get the iOS version ready for TestFlight. Stay tuned!

Finding Joy in Visible Plumbing

Feb 3, 2023

What I came to understand a few years ago: when it comes to writing software, I love creating “visible plumbing”. Let me explain.

When I talk about software development, I use the term “plumbing” to describe backend systems, all the usually invisible infrastructure stuff that makes things work. Sexy headline stuff? No. Important? Absolutely.

“Visible plumbing” is the stuff that helps people achieve their goals and do their jobs, like personal automation. (Ex: obsidian.actions.work).

It may not be shiny, but it’s useful.

And that theme, over the years, has come back to me again and again. Helping my co-workers and people get through their day, building automation for/with them, making the machine that was our company hum a little nicer - that’s my jam.

As its CTO (= resident nerd), I built a shitload (most?) of RECUP’s early digital infrastructure and tools, and I was happy with that, even though I knew it was important, but not something that was visible to people outside the company. I never made the cover of a business magazine or gave any interviews about it. But I knew I was doing important work, and that made me happy.

Or go back even further, about 20 years: I ran a community site for an MMORPG (kids, ask your parents) that focused on in-game “news” and markets. I was that thing that made it easier for others to tell their in-game stories, achieve their goals, have fun. To them, it was useful, and that gave me energy.

Anyway, my point is: I found my “passion” (ğŸ¤®), I realized what gave me joy and what made me tick. I will never be super-rich or super-famous or super-important, and that’s quite alright, because I am content with what I do.

As a software developer or entrepreneur or freelancer, you don’t have to chase the shiny shit, the VC, you don’t have to revolutionize the Whatever, you don’t have to go global, you don’t need to “make it big”. Find an area that’s important to you, big or small (don’t overlook the small things!) and then go do your thing in that area. In my experience, that’s a recipe for getting the most joy out of your work.

Fresh in Flensburg #24: Heimat

Nov 6, 2022

Beim letzten Besuch bei meinen Eltern erzÃ¤hlte mein Vater von einem Bekannten, der auch aus dem Harz weggezogen ist und seit Ã¼ber 20 Jahren in MÃ¼nchen lebt. Die Mutter, seine letzte AngehÃ¶rige, hatte vor einiger Zeit das Elternhaus im Ort verkauft und war in ein nicht weit entferntes Dorf umgezogen. “Das muss ja seltsam sein, wenn man dann so heimatlos ist."

Ummm.

Ich finde nicht, dass er heimatlos ist. FÃ¼r mich ist Heimat der Ort, an dem ich lebe und mit dem ich mich verbunden fÃ¼hle, also mein Lebensmittelpunkt â€” daher ist fÃ¼r mich diese Aussage falsch. Ich komme aus dem Harz: als ich dort lebte, war es meine Heimat, fÃ¼r viele Jahre danach war MÃ¼nchen meine Heimat, jetzt ist es die FÃ¶rde.

Anders gesagt: “Herkunft” ist das Dock, in dem mein Boot gebaut wurde und wo es ins Wasser gelassen wurde; “Heimat” ist der Ort, an dem ich den Anker auswerfe. Wenn man dort wohnt, wo man geboren wurde, kÃ¶nnen die Fragen nach Herkunft und Heimat zwar identisch beantwortet werden, aber es sind trotzdem zwei verschiedene Konzepte.

Wenn ich einen Ort als “Heimat” bezeichne, dann drÃ¼cke ich damit Commitment aus. Ich lasse mich voll darauf ein, ich bin hier, ich bin prÃ¤sent.

Aber wenn z.B. eine schon lange in MÃ¼nchen lebende Person sagt, ihre Heimat sei Leipzig, klingt das fÃ¼r mich immer nach “ich wÃ¤re viel lieber in Leipzig”. (Egal, ob sie es so meint oder nicht. Und beides ist okay, mind.)

Mich irritiert die sprachliche UnschÃ¤rfe. ğŸ˜‰

Let’s do this, then. WofÃ¼r bin ich dieses Jahr dankbar?

  • Wir haben eine trockene, saubere, schÃ¶ne, adÃ¤quat groÃŸe, wirklich bezahlbare Wohnung.
  • Meine Ehe. â¤ï¸
  • Wir kÃ¶nnen selbstbestimmt leben und unseren Wohnort frei und unabhÃ¤ngig wÃ¤hlen.

  • Meiner Familie und mir geht es gut.

  • Meine aktuelle SelbstÃ¤ndigkeit kann sich in Ruhe entfalten und entwickeln, ohne dass ich von Stunde 0 an 24/7 ackern muss, um mich Ã¼ber Wasser zu halten.

  • In der Maslowschen BedÃ¼rfnishierarchie kann ich mich im obersten Segment bewegen.

So this is happening: Actions for Obsidian (macOS/iOS)

Oct 7, 2022

ğŸš€ After a few weeks of foundational work I’m literally quite excited to finally lift the lid on my new appâ€¦

It’s called Actions for Obsidian and adds, well, Obsidian actions to the Shortcuts app on macOS and iOS. If you want to better integrate your note taking with Obsidian and your other workflows, I think you’ll enjoy it.

Check it out @ obsidian.actions.work.

Beta coming soon, sign up for the mailing list if you’re curious. Or just follow the app’s Twitter account, @actionsdotwork. I’d appreciate either or both. ğŸ˜‰

Fresh in Flensburg #20: SÃ¸nderborg

Sep 25, 2022

Eine gute Woche.

Die meisten wachen Stunden verbringe ich derzeit mit Programmieren und Software-Entwicklung, denn nach vielen Monaten der gefÃ¼hlten Ziellosigkeit Ã¼berrollten mich plÃ¶tzlich ein paar gute Ideen, die ich jetzt umsetze. Dazu lerne ich mich gleichzeitig in mehrere Programmiersprachen und Frameworks ein, und arbeite an einem mehrstufigen Projekt, das mit etwas GlÃ¼ck am Ende fÃ¼r etwas Einkommen sorgt. In dieser Woche hatte ich auch meinen ersten 45 Minuten-Termin hier in Flensburg, der richtig gut war. Dann gaben wir unsere Stimmen fÃ¼r die OB-Wahl ab, und auf der Freitags-Klimademo1 waren wir auch noch.

Volle Tage, aber: ğŸš€! Bei all der energiegeladenen guten Laune sollte man trotzdem nicht vergessen, auch mal Pausen oder einen Ausflug zu machen.

SÃ¸nderborg (fÃ¼r deutsche Ohren: “SÃ¶nderbohr”) ist ein dÃ¤nischer Nachbar an der nÃ¶rdlichen Seite der FÃ¶rde. In der UniversitÃ¤tsstadt leben ca. 28.000 Menschen, die Gemeinde blÃ¼ht seit ein paar Jahren anstÃ¤ndig auf, nicht zuletzt auch wegen einiger ansÃ¤ssiger Firmen wie Danfoss, die ordentlich Geld in die Gegend investieren.

Um nach SÃ¸nderborg zu gelangen, bietet sich eine FÃ¶rderundfahrt an. Damit meine ich einen Auto- oder Bustrip von knapp 45 km rund um die FÃ¶rde, denn es gibt keinen grenzÃ¼berschreitenden FÃ¤hrverkehr an den Stellen, an denen man es eigentlich erwarten wÃ¼rde. (Die Region Ã¼berrascht immer wieder!) Die Strecke ist bei sonnigem Wetter extrem schÃ¶n, ruft eine serielle Abfolge von “Hach!"-Momenten hervor und ist dadurch sehr kurzweilig. Die Begeisterung wird schnell anstrengend, es empfiehlt sich ein kurzer Halt fÃ¼r Softeis und Snaccos am in der Gegend weltberÃ¼hmten Annies Kiosk. Der Kiosk ist Ã¼ber die letzten Jahrzehnte zu einer Institution geworden, er darf in keiner TV-Doku Ã¼ber das sÃ¼dliche DÃ¤nemark und die FÃ¶rde-Region fehlen, und kann sogar eine eigene Wikipedia-Seite aufweisen.2 (Huh.) Ein Bekannter und Segler erzÃ¤hlte mir erfreut, dass der Kiosk Ã¼ber einen eigenen Bootsanleger verfÃ¼gt, und die Entfernung nach Flensburg so kurz ist, dass man nach Feierabend fÃ¼r einen Hotdog von FL bis zum Kiosk segeln und noch vor Einbruch der Nacht wieder daheim sein kann. #lifeGoals

Kurz vor dem Fahrtziel kamen wir in DybbÃ¸l an einer groÃŸen MÃ¼hle vorbei, die allerdings so hart nach “dÃ¤nisches Klischee fÃ¼r den Tourismus” aussieht, dass ich nur abwinken und weiterfahren wollte, ohne weiter darÃ¼ber nachzudenken. Allerdings steht die MÃ¼hle dort tatsÃ¤chlich seit 1744 und wurde seitdem mehrfach (wieder-)aufgebaut.3 Vor einigen Jahren spendierte man ihr eine umfassende Renovierung, und jetzt ist sie ein Museum. Trotzdem: it’s a bit much, Leute ğŸ˜‰

Aber dann: SÃ¸nderborg. Eine hÃ¼bsche kleine Stadt! Mein persÃ¶nliches Highlight aber war das Alsik Hotel & Spa, in dem man einerseits auf der Terrasse im Erdgeschoss sehr gemÃ¼tlich Kaffee trinken kann, und das andererseits sein komplettes 17. Stockwerk als Ã¶ffentliche, kostenlose 360Â°-Besucherterrasse zur VerfÃ¼gung stellt. Als sich die LifttÃ¼ren Ã¶ffneten, hat mir der Ausblick etwas die Sprache verschlagen. Wir waren am Vormittag eines Wochentags dort, und hatten die Etage somit nahezu fÃ¼r uns allein. Wirklich, wirklich toll.

Ehrlich, you can’t hate on that view:

Siehst Du auf dem Foto auch die ErdkrÃ¼mmung? Irre!! (Sorry, nein, das ist nur ein Nebeneffekt des Panoramas.) SchÃ¶ne Gegend hier, erwÃ¤hnte ich das schon?

Fresh in Flensburg #19: Etwas Negativ

Sep 18, 2022

Unsere Corona-Infektionen sind Ã¼berstanden: jeweils 4 NÃ¤chte mit Fieber und dazwischen Tage, die typisch sind fÃ¼r heftige ErkÃ¤ltungen, und welche uns dann auch nach dem abschliessenden negativen Test noch eine gute Woche erhalten blieben. Alles in Allem fÃ¼hlte es sich an wie eine g’scheite Grippe, nicht mehr und nicht weniger. Mein Verstand sagt mir, dass die bisherigen vier COVID-Impfungen eine gute Idee waren. Danke, Medizin!

Wenn mÃ¶glich, je nach Tagesverfassung, habe ich auch in der Krankheitszeit meine Runden durch die Hood gedreht. Isolieren kann ich mich auch an der frischen Luft, mit gesundem Abstand zu anderen Menschen. Meine Eltern waren in der Stadt, und auch wenn wir uns nicht umarmen oder ihnen unsere Wohnung zeigen konnten â€” dank Sonnenwetter mit steifem Wind waren wenigstens ein paar SpaziergÃ¤nge und GesprÃ¤che drin. ğŸ‰

Langsam macht sich der Herbst an der FÃ¶rde breit, und das sonnige Sommerwetter wird immer Ã¶fter unterbrochen von kurzen Schauern. (Mir scheint, das Venn-Diagramm “Jahreszeiten an der dÃ¤nischen Grenze” hat nur sehr knappe Ãœberschneidungen, und die Ãœbergangszeiten bemessen sich in Stunden. ğŸ˜‰) Unser erster Herbst hier oben! Aufregend.

Die Ostsee hat ja weder Ebbe noch Flut, was ich sehr schÃ¤tze. (Meere wie die Nordsee werben zwar damit, die “echte See” zu sein, aber was bekommt man dort wirklich? Die HÃ¤lfte der Zeit gibt es nur die HÃ¤lfte vom Meer â€” und niemand hinterfragt diesen etwas zweifelhaften Arbeitsethos? C’mon.) Aber: starker Westwind kann das Wasser aus der FÃ¶rde in die Ostsee schieben, was zu leeren Hafenbecken1 oder auch zu trockengelegten StrÃ¤nden fÃ¼hren kann. Letzteres passiert gerade in der stÃ¼rmischen Saison des Ã–fteren. Als ich das das erste Mal unvorbereitet sah, hat es mich ziemlich verwirrt.

Erste Vermutung: der Zar hat russische MilitÃ¤rkampftrinker nach St. Petersburg geordert, damit sie die Ostsee strategisch leerschlÃ¼rfen. Aber nope: nur das Wetter. Und auch wenn ich weiÃŸ, dass die SolitÃ¼de-Strandabschnitte sehr flach sind â€” ich finde das Zusammenspiel der Naturgewalten beeindruckend: Der Wind drÃ¼ckt Ã¼ber Stunden hinweg gigantische Wassermengen aus der FÃ¶rde hinaus und sorgt fÃ¼r einen 10-15cm niedrigeren Wasserstand. ğŸ¤¯

Aber der Anblick macht mich an manchen Tagen auch etwas traurig, weiÃŸ ich doch, dass sich all das rapide verÃ¤ndert. Studien prognostizieren aufgrund der hausgemachten GrÃ¶nland-Eisschmelze einen Anstieg des Meeresspiegels von 27 bis 78cm bis 21002, hinzu kommt das Abschmelzen des ostantarktischen Eisschildes, welches einen Anstieg von ~5m bis 2300 ausmachen wird.3 Selbst wenn wir heute unseren CO2-AusstoÃŸ einfrieren kÃ¶nnten, die VerÃ¤nderung auf planetarer Ebene ist schon in vollem Gange.

Und so ziehe ich im Kopf sehr oft schon die Wasserlinie neu, wenn ich am Ufer entlang laufe. Auch, wenn ich das eigentlich gar nicht mÃ¶chte; aber es ist, wie es ist, sagt mein gelernter Gleichmut.

Tja, stÃ¼rmische Gedanken an herbstlichen Tagen. Was die Klimakrise tatsÃ¤chlich bewirkt, das habe ich erst wirklich verstanden, als ich nicht mehr in einer GroÃŸstadt wohnte. Ich mag GroÃŸstÃ¤dte, sie haben oft viel zu bieten, aber sie nehmen uns auch den dauerhaften direkten Bezug zur Natur. Okay, ja, die Sommer werden Ã¼berall heiÃŸer â€” aber komplett ausgetrocknete BÃ¶den und WÃ¤lder bleiben ein abstraktes Konzept, wenn um Dich herum weder GÃ¤rten noch wilde BaumbestÃ¤nde zu finden sind; steigende Meeresspiegel bleiben Theorie, wenn das Meer nicht zu Deinem tÃ¤glichen Leben gehÃ¶rt usw.

Puh.

Trotzdem: nicht verzagen, nicht aufgeben. âœŠğŸ¼ Ich bin mir sicher, dass die FÃ¶rde auch mit mehr Wasser toll sein wird.

Abschliessender medizinischer Tipp, weil ich es auch vor ein paar Tagen erst wieder gemacht habe: geht zur Apotheke und lasst einen Vitamin D-Test durchfÃ¼hren. (Das kostet so um die 30â‚¬.) Vitamin D ist ein Hormon, welches vom KÃ¶rper primÃ¤r Ã¼ber die Haut bei Sonneneinstrahlung gebildet wird, und sich ganz entscheidend auf die Stimmung auswirkt. Gerade in der kÃ¤lteren und dunkleren Jahreszeit sind bei vielen Menschen die Vitamin D-Level sehr gering, was zu Schwermut bis hin zu Depression fÃ¼hren kann. In der Apotheke gibt’s bei einem solchen Test i.d.R. auch eine Beratung, ob und wie man die kÃ¶rpereigene Vitamin D-Versorgung aufpÃ¤ppeln kann. Diese Art von LebensqualitÃ¤t ist relativ einfach zu haben. ğŸ‘ğŸ¼

Dieser Post ist Teil meines “Fresh in Flensburg”-Newsletters. Ab Mitte April 2022 schreibe ich fÃ¼r knapp 6 Monate jede Woche eine Mail mit EindrÃ¼cken, Erlebnissen und vielleicht auch Fotos zu und aus “meiner” neuen Stadt. Ausgabe #25 wird das Staffelfinale.

  3. FAZ: “Der sensible Eispanzer der Antarktis”. Die FAZ schreibt “WÃ¼rde das in Paris vereinbarte Zwei-Grad-Ziel nicht erreicht, kÃ¶nnten erhebliche Teile der Ostantarktis schmelzen” â€” ich bin mir sicher, der Konjunktiv ist fehl am Platz. ↩︎

How to hide Youtube videos based on their title using uBlock Origin

Sep 4, 2022

I don’t like “reaction videos” as they’re some of the laziest filler material you can come up with. In my experience, 99 out of 100 times, they’re a waste of time for everyone involved. (I feel sorry for the remaining one good video, though.)

Thanks to the new :has() selector (Chrome 105 and up) it’s now trivially easy to filter Youtube lists/grids for videos based on their title.

Take this new-found possibility and combine it with the power of uBlock Origin and you’ll never have to see a reaction video again.

This screenshot shows filters for “reacts” & “reactions”:

Here’s the example filters for copying into your uBO config:

# YT grid view
www.youtube.com##ytd-rich-item-renderer:has(yt-formatted-string[aria-label*=" REACTION " i])
www.youtube.com##ytd-rich-item-renderer:has(yt-formatted-string[aria-label*=" REACTS " i])

# YT list/results view
www.youtube.com##ytd-video-renderer:has(yt-formatted-string[aria-label*=" REACTION " i])
www.youtube.com##ytd-video-renderer:has(yt-formatted-string[aria-label*=" REACTS " i])

# YT video wall
www.youtube.com##a.ytp-videowall-still[aria-label*=" REACTION " i]
www.youtube.com##a.ytp-videowall-still[aria-label*=" REACTS " i]

# YT suggested videos bar
www.youtube.com##ytd-compact-video-renderer:has(span[aria-label*=" REACTION " i])
www.youtube.com##ytd-compact-video-renderer:has(span[aria-label*=" REACTS " i])

Notice the extra spaces in " REACTS “ and ” REACTION “, I found they help to prevent false positives (where “reaction” is part of another word). Both filters are case-insensitive, too, so they’ll filter out “reacts”, “REACTS”, “Reacts” etc.

Tags: #youtube #howto #ublockorigin

Update 2022-09-05T17:32:51Z: added filters for YT video wall and YT suggested videos bar.

Fresh in Flensburg #18: Jeans

Aug 28, 2022

Wohnungen sind wie Jeans.

An unserer letzten Adresse in MÃ¼nchen wohnten wir 16 Jahre. Ich kann mich nicht mehr daran erinnern, wie ungewohnt und neu sich alles in der ersten Zeit angefÃ¼hlt hat, aber ich weiÃŸ, dass es so war. Wir vergrÃ¶ÃŸerten uns von ca. 60 auf 100mÂ², und das Mehr an Platz war toll. Wir fÃ¼llten die RÃ¤ume relativ schnell mit Zeug und mitgebrachten Erinnerungen, mit WÃ¼nschen und Ideen, was die Zukunft sicher alles bringen wird; einige der Ideen waren Leihgaben und eigentlich schon lange Ã¼ber ihrem MHD, aber das begriffen wir erst nach und nach.

Das Haus war dabei ein wenig wie ein neues KleidungsstÃ¼ck, das schon beim Kauf mit Hoffnungen Ã¼berfrachtet wird. Mit diesen Schuhen werde ich endlich zu joggen beginnen! In diesem Kleid kann ich auf legendÃ¤re Parties gehen! Diese Leggings machen mich zum Yoga-Monster! Dieses Shirt wird groÃŸartig in den Nachrichten aussehen, wenn ich den Nobel-Preis fÃ¼r planloses GÃ¤rtnern in Empfang nehme! Diese Jeans rÃ¼ckt meinen Hintern gut ins Spotlight!

Aber wie es so ist mit neuer Kleidung: Erst wenn man sie trÃ¤gt, lernt man sie richtig kennen und sieht, ob und wie sie wirklich passt, was man in ihr machen kann und machen mÃ¶chte. Die Sneaker sind klasse, aber ich gehe lieber damit spazieren als joggen; das Kleid ist schÃ¶n, aber es bringt nicht automatisch mehr Parties in mein Leben; die Leggings machen meine bessere HÃ¤lfte rollig, aber das mit dem Yoga wird irgendwie nichts; das Shirt ist nur meh, und ich finde GÃ¤rtnern doof.

Erst wenn man sich wirklich auf ein neues Domizil und dessen Umgebung einlÃ¤sst, und versteht, wie es bewohnt werden mÃ¶chte, kann es sich richtig anfÃ¼hlen. In unserer alten Wohnung brauchte dieser Prozess tatsÃ¤chlich ein paar Jahre. Wir rÃ¤umten sie ein, um, um, um, aus, ein, um, aus, um â€” und irgendwann fanden wir zusammen eine gute Balance bei MÃ¶beln, Deko, Licht und Freiraum, die fÃ¼r uns Drei1 passte. Das war schÃ¶n.

Die Jeans formte den Hintern also etwas anders, als wir anfangs dachten â€” aber sie saÃŸ nach einiger Zeit verdammt gut.

Wir sind jetzt etwas mehr als drei Monate hier oben. Ich habe mich eingelebt, auch wenn die ersten Wochen innerhalb und ausserhalb der eigenen vier WÃ¤nde alles fremd erschien. An manchen Tagen habe ich immer noch das irritierende GefÃ¼hl, dass ich hier nur als Gast bin und demnÃ¤chst wieder heimfahren muss, aber auch das wird vergehen. ğŸ˜‚

Wir kamen mit wenig, merkten aber recht schnell, dass wir immer noch zu viele MÃ¶bel besaÃŸen. Wir mochten sie nach wie vor, aber manche funktionierten einfach nicht in der neuen Bleibe: Der Platz war zwar vorhanden, aber die Wohnung selbst war nicht der richtige Platz fÃ¼r sie. Wir fanden ihnen also ein neues Zuhause in der Nachbarschaft, in DÃ¤nemark und in Hamburg. #noWaste

DafÃ¼r kamen neue StÃ¼cke in unsere Wohnung, mit denen wir und die RÃ¤ume sich wohlfÃ¼hlen. Das meiste steht da, wo es stehen soll, wo es sich derzeit richtig anfÃ¼hlt. Nicht zu leer, nicht zu voll, alles da inklusive Luft zum Atmen.

Anders ausgedrÃ¼ckt: Die neue Jeans sitzt tight und mein Arsch sieht fantastisch darin aus.

Zeit, neue Leute kennenzulernen!

Die Flensburger Innenstadt besteht gefÃ¼hlt zu 20% aus Leerstand, zu dem Corona und Lockdowns sicherlich ihren Teil beigetragen haben. Der traurige Blick der verwaisten und verschlossenen GeschÃ¤fte folgt den Besucher:innen, die durch GroÃŸe StraÃŸe, Holm und NorderstraÃŸe schlendern. Das ist ein grundsÃ¤tzliches Problem wie in vielen anderen StÃ¤dten auch; wenn sich der Leerstand ausbreitet, wird die Gegend unattraktiver fÃ¼r die Anwohner, die zivile Gesellschaft und GeschÃ¤ftstreibende.

Wie ich in dieser Woche bei einem spontanen Besuch in der coolen kleinen Urbanica Art Gallery2 im schnieken KÃ¤the-Lassen-Hof erfahren durfte, investiert Flensburg in eine Abteilung Innenstadtmanagement! Dieses hat die Aktion “Deine Innenstadt, Deine Ideen” ausgerufen, und in der Urbanica einen entsprechenden Workshop veranstaltet. Mit 630.000â‚¬ im FÃ¶rdertopf sucht FL nach neuen Ideen, um seinen Kern zu beleben. Ich kam schnell mit Emin (Urbanica + ein halbes Dutzend andere Ventures) und Bela, Jenny & SÃ¶nke (Stadt FL) ins GesprÃ¤ch Ã¼ber MÃ¶glichkeiten, Ideen und gesellschaftliche Fragen (“Wem gehÃ¶rt die Stadt, der Ã¶ffentliche Raum?" etc.). Gute Themen!

Mein Lamento “Mir fehlt Co-Working in der Stadtmitte” beantwortete Bela grinsend mit “Wir helfen Dir mit den AntrÃ¤gen, wenn Du selbst einen Space erÃ¶ffnen willst!!". Will ich? Uhâ€¦ nicht im Moment, aber gut zu wissen, danke! ğŸ˜‰

Aussagen wie diese trugen zum Eindruck bei, den ich aus diesen 2h mitgenommen habe: hier sind Menschen, die tatsÃ¤chlich an Ideen und Brainstorming interessiert sind; die helfen wollen, Projekte auf die StraÃŸe zu bringen; und die unsere Stadt dabei nicht zwangslÃ¤ufig als Initiatorin, aber definitiv als MÃ¶glichmacherin sehen. ğŸ‘ğŸ¼

Und ja: nur FÃ¶rde, Flens-Brauerei und Fahrzeugbau allein reichen nicht aus, um eine prosperierende, attraktive und lebenswerte Stadt zu erhalten. Was diese auch anerkennt und aktiv vorantreibt, mit dem “Flensburg 2030”-Stadtentwicklungsprozess und dem Bekenntnis zur Neuen Leipzig Charta3: sie will grÃ¼n (Ã¶kologisch, umweltfreundlich), gerecht (sozial) und nachhaltig-produktiv (Ã¶konomisch) bleiben und/oder werden. 3 von 3, genau mein Ding!

Dieser Post ist Teil meines “Fresh in Flensburg”-Newsletters. Ab Mitte April 2022 schreibe ich fÃ¼r knapp 6 Monate jede Woche eine Mail mit EindrÃ¼cken, Erlebnissen und vielleicht auch Fotos zu und aus “meiner” neuen Stadt. Ausgabe #25 wird das Staffelfinale.

  3. Lesenswert: “Die Neue Leipzig-Charta ist das Leitdokument fÃ¼r gemeinwohlorientierte Stadtentwicklung in Europa. Sie formuliert konkrete Handlungsdimensionen und SchlÃ¼sselprinzipien guter Stadtpolitik." ↩︎

Toleranz ist ein Friedensabkommen

Aug 22, 2022

Yonatan Zunger hat den Begriff der Toleranz definiert (auf Englisch), und es sehr gut auf den Punkt gebracht (meine Ãœbersetzung):

Toleranz ist kein moralisches Absolutum, sie ist ein Friedensabkommen. Toleranz ist eine gesellschaftliche Norm, weil sie es unterschiedlichen Menschen ermÃ¶glicht, Seite an Seite zu leben, ohne sich gegenseitig an die Kehle zu gehen. Das bedeutet, dass wir akzeptieren, dass andere Menschen anders sind als wir, in ihren Sitten, ihrem Verhalten, ihrer Kleidung, ihrem Sexualleben, und dass uns das nichts angeht, wenn es sich nicht direkt auf unser Leben auswirkt. Aber das Modell eines Friedensabkommens unterscheidet sich vom Modell eines moralischen Gebots in einem einfachen Aspekt: Der Schutz eines Friedensabkommens erstreckt sich nur auf diejenigen, die bereit sind, sich an seine Bedingungen zu halten. Es ist eine Vereinbarung, in Frieden zu leben â€” aber keine Vereinbarung, friedlich zu sein, gleichgÃ¼ltig, wie die Anderen sich verhalten. Ein Friedensabkommen ist kein Selbstmordpakt.

Wenn also das nÃ¤chste Mal jemand auf das scheinbare Paradox hinweist, warum wir ihre/seine Intoleranz nicht tolerieren kÃ¶nnen wollen: Dies ist die beste, eingÃ¤ngigste, einfachste ErklÃ¤rung dafÃ¼r, die ich bislang gefunden habe.

(Offenbar hat er diesen Text schon 2017 verfasst, aber er war neu fÃ¼r mich.)

Fresh in Flensburg #17: Raus aus der Stadt

Aug 21, 2022

Wenn ich es beschreiben mÃ¶chte, vermeide ich den Begriff “wandern” bewusst.

“Wandern”, das klingt nach groÃŸem Rucksack, Anglerhut, nach festem Schuhwerk und Jakobsweg. Nach Hochschullehrern im Ruhestand und dem vergnÃ¼glichen Schnaufen durch die RhÃ¶n oder die SÃ¤chsische Schweiz. Nach klaren Tagesetappen und zeitlich geplantem Absacker im auf Google Maps gut bewerteten Restaurant.

Nichts gegen all das (you do you, liebe Hochschullehrer im Ruhestand!), aber das ist nicht, was ich tue. Zum Einen: Nur wenig bis keine Vorbereitung; nur kleines bis kein GepÃ¤ck; nur ein grober bis gar kein Plan. Zum Anderen: â€¦ hmmmm.

Hmm.

Einer meiner Lieblingsautoren, der in Japan lebende US-Amerikaner Craig Mod, schreibt groÃŸartige, berÃ¼hrende Essays und BÃ¼chern Ã¼ber das “Walking”. Seine Walks sind sehr oft sehr lang; genÃ¼gen mir meist 5â€“10 km, um mich zu leveln, so ist er oft Ã¼ber Tage hinweg unterwegs, durchmisst Ã¼ber hunderte Kilometer hinweg seine Heimat Japan oder auf Reisen England und Australien. Sie sind zu gleichen Teilen notwendiger Offline-Ausgleich, ein Ausatmen, ein Sammeln von neuer Kraft, Mediation, Inspiration, GlÃ¼ck, das Nachgehen von Neugier und das Zelebrieren von Menschen, Natur, StÃ¤dten. All das, all das zusammen. And I get it: Beim Lesen seiner Essays spÃ¼re ich tief in mir drin ein andÃ¤chtiges Nicken, die Worte und Gedanken resonieren. Das. Genau das ist es. Good stuff.

Nur: Diese FÃ¼lle an Bedeutungen macht es mir schwer, ein passendes deutsches Wort fÃ¼r diesen allumfassenden Begriff “Walk” zu finden. Oderâ€¦ ist das Wandern, und Anglerhut und Pilgerweg sind optionalâ€½

Aber vielleicht ist das genaue Benennen auch nicht notwendig; mÃ¶glicherweise reicht die Beschreibung aus, so dass Du auch trotz meines Mangels an passenden Worten verstehst, welche GefÃ¼hle ich beschreiben mÃ¶chte. Oder aber Du wÃ¼rdest auch nach hunderten weiteren Worten nur freundlich mit den Schultern zucken. (Beides okay, so oder so danke fÃ¼r’s Lesen.ğŸ˜‰)

Sei’s drum: Ich wandere also.

An manchen Tagen ist kein Walk einfach keine Option, dann drÃ¤ngt es mich raus, Strecke machen. Vielleicht muss ich meinen Kopf lÃ¼ften; vielleicht fÃ¼hlt sich die Welt gerade mal wieder an wie ein viel zu enger Sweater; vielleicht stecken Ideen und Gedanken fest und brauchen das, was die alten RÃ¶mer mit solvitur ambulando (“es wird durch Gehen gelÃ¶st”) beschrieben haben. Carlo braucht etwas Carlo-Zeit, let’s roll.

Die Runde heute fÃ¼hrt mich zum Quellental in GlÃ¼cksburg. Erstmal nach Westen, raus aus der Stadt. Hinter mir MÃ¼rwik, vorbei an gepflegten ReihenhÃ¤usern, durch die kleinen StraÃŸen mit den schmucken Einfamiliendomizilen. Ich sehe die StrebergÃ¤rten mit ihren immer viel zu kurzen Rasen, die der Sonne nichts mehr entgegenzusetzen haben, in denen die obligatorischen MÃ¤h- bald durch Staubsaugerroboter ersetzt werden kÃ¶nnen, wenn dann nur noch Staub zwischen den Hecken und BÃ¼schen liegt. ğŸ¤·ğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸ Hinter der letzten Siedlung in Tremmerup empfÃ¤ngt mich der alte freundliche Wald wie eine kÃ¼hle Dusche, die Hitze fÃ¤llt von mir ab. AdÃ¤quat holprige Waldwege fÃ¼hren mich unter hohen Baumkronen an kleinen Seen und MoorflÃ¤chen vorbei, ich erahne Meierwik mit seinem fantastischen Blick Ã¼ber die FÃ¶rde mehr als dass ich es durch die BÃ¼sche sehe. Durch Zufall entdecke ich den Roikier See;1 die Reflexionen der Sonne zwischen all den Seerosen lÃ¤sst mich fast erblinden, und ich habe Kindheit-Flashbacks an Zeltplatzurlaube und Faltboot-AusflÃ¼ge zu Waldseen. Kurze Pause fÃ¼r die obligatorische Handvoll Brombeeren, eine Radfahrerin ruft mir lachend “Guten Appetit” zu. Thanks, girl! Ich glaube, bis jetzt habe ich hier im Wald max. 10 Menschen auf FahrrÃ¤dern oder neben ihren Hunden gesehen; wir tauschen kurze freundliche “Moin!“s aus, und lassen uns sonst gegenseitig sein. Chill.

Eine halbe Stunde spÃ¤ter erreiche ich das “Quellental”, ein schÃ¶nes kleines CafÃ©/Restaurant am gleichnamigen Ausflugsgebiet direkt neben einem poshen Yachthafen. Hier kann man gut essen! Neue Erfahrung: nur die Kuchen sind ausg’schamt teuer und (schlimmer) der Kaffee ist dÃ¼nnes MittelmaÃŸ, trotz SiebtrÃ¤germaschine. Ich hatte groÃŸe Hoffnungen, Quellental.2 ğŸ˜¢

Der RÃ¼ckweg fÃ¼hrt mich oben am waldigen Steilufer entlang, die FÃ¶rde nur einen Steinwurf und/ oder schreienden Sturz entfernt. Das Quellental ist ein groÃŸer Wald, der auch einen Ruheforst beherbergt. Es ist schÃ¶n und wundervoll ruhig hier, wirkt aber in den 25 m vor dem Abhang teilweise seltsam aufgerÃ¤umt. Die LÃ¶sung fÃ¼r dieses RÃ¤tsel: Menschen, die abends unten am Strand Lagerfeuer machen und dafÃ¼r altes Holz benÃ¶tigen, Feuerwarnstufe egal, schliesslich ist man direkt am Wasser. Nun ja.

Ich halte mich in UfernÃ¤he, und komme nach einer knappen halben Stunde nach Meierwik, einem Ortsteil von GlÃ¼cksburg, der nahtlos an Flensburg anschliesst (und somit definitiv nÃ¤her an FL als an GlÃ¼cksburg liegt). Dann kommt SolitÃ¼de, wo ich mich jedesmal auf’s Neue frage, wie ich wohl an so ein be-nei-dens-wert gelegenes GrundstÃ¼ck komme, und damit bin ich fast schon wieder daheim.

Knapp 13 km; ich bin ausgepowert und zufrieden. Die Probleme der Welt konnte ich nicht lÃ¶sen, aber zumindest weiÃŸ ich wieder, dass ich das auch nicht muss.

Ganz egal, wie ich es nenne: Walk, Wanderung, whatever. Es tut mir gut.

Dieser Post ist Teil meines “Fresh in Flensburg”-Newsletters. Ab Mitte April 2022 schreibe ich fÃ¼r knapp 6 Monate jede Woche eine Mail mit EindrÃ¼cken, Erlebnissen und vielleicht auch Fotos zu und aus “meiner” neuen Stadt. Ausgabe #25 wird das Staffelfinale.

Fresh in Flensburg #16: Klimaflucht

Aug 14, 2022

Trigger-Warnung: KlimaverÃ¤nderung.

Es ist definitiv zu heiÃŸ fÃ¼r ungetrÃ¼bt gute Laune.

August 2021: “Flensburg ist toll, und die Wetterlage hier oben ist super! Ich glaube, hier wird es auch nicht so wahnsinnig heiÃŸ, wegen Ost- und Nordsee nebenan, es wird weniger extreme AusschlÃ¤ge geben, was glaubst Du?" â€” “Sehe ich genau so, let’s do this!"

August 2022: “Holy shit, es ist bitte WIE HEIÃŸ in MÃ¼nchenâ€½ Ist Dir klar, dass wir auf eine gewisse Art KlimaflÃ¼chtlinge sindâ€½Â ğŸ˜³”

Wenn ich dieser Tage auf die Wetterkarte von Deutschland schaue, sehe ich tiefrote Zahlen. WÃ¤lder brennen und vertrocknen; der Harz (wo ich geboren bin und wo meine Blutfamilie wohnt) ist in groÃŸen Teilen nahezu kahl, dahingerafft von jahrzehntelanger Monokultur, von Trockenheit und von BorkenkÃ¤fern in einer fatalen Abfolge. GroÃŸe FlÃ¼sse und Seen trocknen rapide aus, und SÃ¼ddeutschland erreicht teilweise subtropische Temperaturen. Die Wetterextreme rund ums Jahr werden hÃ¤rter, das haben wir selbst die letzten zehn Jahre schon in MÃ¼nchen beobachtet. Trinkwasser wird auch hierzulande Ã¶fters knapp.

Wir als Menschheit sind in der Phase angelangt, in der das Fortschreiten der exponentiellen KlimaverÃ¤nderungen spÃ¼rbar wird, und ich will nicht lÃ¼gen: Es macht mir Angst. Nur Idioten haben keine Angst davor. Ohne Ãœbertreibung: ich bange um die Meinen sÃ¼dlich von mir, und hoffe, dass sie die wachsenden Extreme weiter gut Ã¼berstehen werden. Das wird nichts, was man aussitzen kann, dies ist nun unser stÃ¤ndiger Begleiter. Dana und ich nehmen die VerÃ¤nderungen schon seit Jahren wahr, wie viele andere aufmerksame Menschen auch, nur werden sie zunehmend drastischer.

Aber unsere EinschÃ¤tzung hat sich bisher bewahrheitet; auch hier wird es warm und teils auch heiÃŸ, ja, aber die nÃ¶rdlichen Meere fangen Einiges ab, gleichen die harten AusschlÃ¤ge noch aus. Und auch wenn ich die Sonne und den Sommer echt mag und geniesse: Die Stimme im Hinterkopf gibt keine Ruh'. Ich weiÃŸ, dass sie Teil eines Chores ist, dass nicht nur ich diese Stimme im Kopf hÃ¶re, nur verbessert das halt die Situation nicht.

Trotzdem bleibt mein Optimismus, auch wenn er es schwerer hat als noch vor 5â€“10Â Jahren. Vor vielen Jahren habe ich ein Interview mit dem Autor Kim Stanley Robinson gelesen1, in dem er ungefÃ¤hr Folgendes gesagt hat: “As a species, we must be optimistic, because we can’t afford to be pessimistic”.2 Das kann ich nicht vergessen, es ist fÃ¼r mich so ein Leuchtturm-Satz geworden â€” etwas, das mich leitet.

Optimismus fÃ¼r mich ist das Benennen der RealitÃ¤t, egal wie gut oder schlecht, verbunden mit der Hoffnung auf Verbesserung, und dem Anerkennen, dass diese sicher nicht ohne aktives BemÃ¼hen erreicht wird â€” aber dass sie erreicht werden kann. (Pessimismus dagegen ist Stagnation, das “Es wird eh nichts mehr, also warum sich bemÃ¼hen?" â€” fatal.)

Ja, die RealitÃ¤t kÃ¶nnte echt besser sein. Klimakrise, Waldsterben, Pandemien. Aber eben auch: weltweit endlich mehr Energie (ahem) beim Ausbau der Erneuerbaren, Geld fÃ¼r die Erforschung neuer nachhaltigerer Energiequellen, eine Renaissance in Medizin und Biotechnologie. Wir werden Ã¼berleben, auch wenn niemand sagen kann, wie die Welt dann in 50â€“100 Jahren aussehen wird, und wie hart die Zeit bis dahin wird.

Ich werde meinen Teil dazu beitragen, klein oder groÃŸ, aber dazu muss ich (biologisch) funktionieren, und das kann ich besser bei kÃ¼hleren Temperaturen. Und vielleicht bedeutet das in ein paar Jahren einen weiteren Umzug â€” mal sehen.

Aaaaaaaaaaaaaanyways.

Ich komme vermutlich demnÃ¤chst an den Punkt, an dem ich genug Brombeeren hatte. Never thought I’d see the day.

Oh, und lest mehr Kim Stanley Robinson! Er schreibt optimistische Science Fiction (Optimismus wie von mir beschrieben). Oft spielen die Handlungen in der nahen Zukunft, er extrapoliert dafÃ¼r sehr gekonnt Entwicklungen und Probleme im Heute, zeigt Auswirkungen und auch immer mÃ¶gliche LÃ¶sungen auf, gepaart mit viel Hoffnung und Ideen. Much, much love.

Dieser Post ist Teil meines “Fresh in Flensburg”-Newsletters. Ab Mitte April 2022 schreibe ich fÃ¼r knapp 6 Monate jede Woche eine Mail mit EindrÃ¼cken, Erlebnissen und vielleicht auch Fotos zu und aus “meiner” neuen Stadt. Ausgabe #25 wird das Staffelfinale.
